awd_titl_txt: IUSE/PFE: RED: Additive Innovation: An Educational Ecosystem of Making and Risk Taking
awd_abstract_narration:
The Polytechnic School at Arizona State University focuses on the education ecosystem that empowers faculty to be agents of change in the way that they teach engineering courses -- with a special focus on the four year project sequence, the 2nd and 3rd year engineering fundamentals courses, and the upper division concentration area disciplinary courses. The project takes a systems and community building perspective on how to sustain a mindset of risk-taking, making and innovation to instill creative confidence in students and faculty. The project approaches this challenge by attending to the larger ecosystem within which innovation happens, and by using evidence-based methods to make continuous teaching and learning advances within the engineering program. The specific objectives of this project are to:

1. Characterize the ecosystem within the Polytechnic School to establish the foundation for enacting innovation across the faculty, impacting students and other stakeholders.
2. Realize a mindset of additive innovation in the students and faculty to promote sharing, scaling, sustainability, and propagation of unique understandings within the community.
3. Establish an understanding of the engineering program culture and dynamics to assess the catalysts and barriers to establishing a culture that is risk seeking.
4. Identify and implement administrative structures to support cultural change and remove perceived barriers that may inhibit such innovation.

This project leverages several pedagogical innovations from the project team's prior research. For example, making is integrated into the curriculum; the Lean Launchpad methodology is implemented to characterize the engineering educational ecosystem; and previously tested/refined engineering education research methods are implemented, particularly as it relates to the project team's expertise on faculty development, in order to contribute knowledge on advancing engineering faculty teaching practices. By taking an entrepreneurial approach and using a rapid and iterative process of customer/user/stakeholder discovery, the project captures influencers and potential barriers of the ecosystem that contribute to, or inhibit impact of the proposed work. This research provides guidance for how to establish administrative structures that lead to supporting faculty as change agents, and how embracing a mindset of making and risk-taking can lead to desired professional competencies in engineering students. Characterizing the ecosystem within which change happens serves as a model for other engineering programs that strive to excel in their educational enterprise. The leadership team is disseminating all aspects of this project using an additive innovation philosophy so that others can modify and improve innovations for their own context. The longer-term impacts of creating a culture that values risk taking and making include attracting a new kind of student to the field of engineering. In particular, students who seek out career options in which they can make a positive impact on the world or on their specific community may not have traditionally considered engineering but now may consider it as a career choice. By changing the conversation from having an impact to having the agency to make an impact, the project aims to engender a measurable increase in student interest and persistence.

por.por_cntn:
Contributions to Knowledge

This project contributed to knowledge by developing tools to investigate both the institutional culture itself and the challenges accompanying revolution within an engineering department.

 

Specific contributions of this project have included:

  • Faculty Pedagogical Risk-Taking Instrument: We developed an instrument to measure faculty attitudes toward taking risks in their teaching practices. This effort supported assessment of the catalysts and barriers to establishing a risk-seeking culture. 

  • Communal Observations of New EXperiences in Teaching (CONEXT) Protocol: We designed a protocol to support the creation of a self-sustaining community of pedagogical exploration. This effort innovated status quo professional development protocols by asking questions to ensure educators receive targeted and useful formative feedback and peer observers think about how they might apply similar teaching practices in their own classroom(s).

  • Capturing the Engineering Program Culture: We used Schein?s organizational cultural framework and a critical incident narrative research approach to better understand the engineering program culture and dynamics. This approach analyzed faculty members? experiences around critical incidents in the organization?s history to assess the culture of the overall program.  Other programs can adopt this same approach to develop an understanding of their own organizational cultures.

  • Studying Making in the Mezzanine: Qualitative research was conducted to understand three case studies of making-based pedagogy in our mezzanine-level mechanics, robotics, and statistics courses.  These efforts supported extending making further into the curriculum.

  • Understanding the Effect of COVID-19 Disruption on Faculty Pedagogical Practices: We surveyed faculty about the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on the delivery of their courses. The intent was to harness what could be learned from this difficult time, providing individual faculty with formative feedback on changes made due to the pandemic and the community with new ideas for pedagogical risks and additive innovation.

  • Tracing Impact Beyond ASU: Our tracing impact work explored the impact of our project beyond the local context. We received nearly twenty requests from other institutions to share our successful RED proposal. We interviewed eleven participants who received our proposal to garner insights surrounding the challenges they hoped to address within their programs and to understand our proposal?s influence in helping frame their approach.

  • Investigating Power in Transdisciplinary Teams: We analyzed interviews of faculty members on RED teams to investigate power and privilege in transdisciplinary teams using an intersectional approach. In addition, workshops at several conferences helped faculty understand power and privilege on teams and how to dismantle common power structures in academia more broadly.

 

Institutional Impact at Arizona State University

Central to our revolution has been the development of multi-level ecosystem models to understand the current institutional landscape and strategically plan institutional changes.

 

Specific impacts of this project at ASU have included:

  • Faculty Innovation Canvas: Entrepreneurial concepts from the business model canvas (BMC) were adapted into a new Faculty Innovation Canvas (FIC) to understand different customer segments and associated value propositions within the school ecosystem. The FIC helped us identify administrative structures that had the potential for sustained change (such as the establishment of a Teaching and Learning Hub) and create the following developmental activities to support and incentivize faculty achievement of their goals.
  • Faculty NEXUS: The NEXUS engaged faculty (and indirectly, students) in realizing a mindset of additive innovation that promotes sharing, scaling, sustainability, and propagation of risk-taking within our engineering program. 
  • Poly Faculty Fellows Program: PFF enabled faculty to propose and implement curricular innovations with support from the school and project. 
  • Poly Pedagogical Ninjas Program: PPN engaged faculty in a series of additive innovation-based professional development activities in which they 1) became inspired by what other members of the pedagogical community were doing in their classes, 2) shared and learned about pedagogical ideas and artifacts, 3) iterated on their own pedagogical ideas and artifacts, and 4) disseminated the results of their pedagogical innovations back to the pedagogical community. This highly successful program resulted in the cross-pollination of ideas amongst faculty, lasting changes in the pedagogical approaches used by participants, and deep qualitative study on the effectiveness of faculty interventions in developing additive innovation and pedagogical risk-taking mindsets. 
  • IDEAS Course: The ASU Engineering Education Systems and Design Ph.D. program now engages all of its students in using the BMC to explore how to scale and sustain educational innovations as part of the Innovation and Design in Engineering Academic Settings (IDEAS) course.
